sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The LexisNexis HPCC technology is designed to effectively process, analyze, and find links and associations within high volumes of complex data. The LexisNexis HPCC technology can detect non-obvious relationships, scale to support petabytes of data, and is significantly faster than competing technologies while requiring less hardware and resources.
This translates into better quality answers in less time so that organizations can cope with massive data and turn information into knowledge.
This document will show you how to obtain and build an HPCC system using the open source model.
OUTLINE DRAFT:
Description:
This file is the top level handling for cmake based compilation and build process.
To build for Linux:
1. Check out sources (for example, to directory ~/hpcc)
2. Create a build directory - either as a child of hpcc or elsewhere
3. cd to the build directory
4a.To create makefiles to build native release version for local machine, run cmake ~/hpcc
4b.To create makefiles to build native debug version, run cmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug ~/hpcc
4c.To create makefiles to build 32-bit version from 64-bit host, run cmake -DCMAKE_C_FLAGS:STRING="-m32 -march=i386" -DCMAKE_CXX_FLAGS:STRING="-m32 -march=i386" ~/hpcc
5. To build the makefiles just created above, run make
6. Executables will be created in ./<releasemode>/bin and ./<releasemode>/libs
To build for Windows:
1. Check out sources (for example, to directory c:\hpcc)
2. Create a build directory - either as a child of hpcc or elsewhere
3. cd to the build directory

4. To create a Visual Studio project, run cmake c:\hpcc -G "Visual Studio 9 2008" The sln file hpccsystems-platform.sln will be created in the current directory, and will support debug and release targets
5. To build the project, load the solution into the visual studio IDE and build in the usual way. 6. Executables will be created in (for example) c:\hpcc\bin\<release_mode>

chapter.title: Hardware and Software Requirements
chapter.para: The following section describes the various hardware and software required in order to run the HPCC.

sect1.title: Switch
sect1.para: A significant component of HPCC is the infrastructure it runs on, specifically the switch.

listitem.para: Sufficient number of ports to allow all nodes to be connected directly to it;
Managed and monitored (SNMP is a plus)

sect1.title: Nodes-Hardware
sect1.para: The HPCC can run as a single node system or a multi node system.

listitem.para: Optionally 3 or more hard drives can be configured in a RAID 5 container for increased performance
Optionally IPMI and KVM over IP support

sect1.title: Nodes-Software
sect1.para: We recommend all nodes have identical operating systems and packages installed. This significantly reduces variables when troubleshooting.

listitem.para: LINUX Ubuntu 9.10 or later and Debian x.xx

sect2.title: Dependencies and packages
sect2.para: Running HPCC depends on having these required component packages listed below installed on the system. For details of the commands recommended for obtaining these packages, see Specific OS Software Installation commands section in appendix of the GettingStarted document.

listitem.para: The GNU Compiler Collection (GCC) with G++ support (required only on the ECL Server node)
Xalan-c 1.10.0 (rpm - fedora epel repository or via source)
Xalan-c-devel 1.10.0 (rpm - fedora epel repository or via source)
Xerces-c 2.7.0 (rpm - fedora epel repository or via source)
Xerces-c-devel 2.7.0 (rpm - fedora epel repository or via source)
Running HPCC requires communicating with the system from your workstation with a browser
You will need to use one of the supported web browsers with Javascript enabled.
If browser security is set to High, you should add ECLWatch as a Trusted Site to allow Javascript execution.
HPCC Client Tools (ECL IDE). See the ECLWatch web page to download the Windows install set.
The Client tools were designed to run on Windows machines. See the appendix for instructions on running them on Linux workstations using Wine.

chapter.title: Getting and Installing the Source
chapter.para: This part of the document will discuss ways to get the source code and install it.

sect1.title: Sources of Source
sect1.para: The source code can be found on the LexisNexis Portal at ***link to portal***. Register with the NIM*** site to be able to download the source package.
The source package is in the form of a source tarfile. (.stgz) download the file from the site to the machine where you wish to install the HPCC.

sect1.title: Installing the Source files
sect1.para: Extract the source files into a working directory. You may want to create a directory for the source files. You would also want to have a directory for the binaries.
For instance, if we wanted to extract to /users/home/hpcc9 we could issue the command:
tar -xzvf hpcc.tar.gz –C /usr/home/hpcc9/ This will be the directory of the source, here we would create a directory for the binaries.
mkdir cmake_build9 Then from the new cmake_build9 directory, you can issue the command:
cmake /usr/home/hpcc9This will give lots of messages and status as the process runs.

Once this process successfully completes, you can then issue the command:make Make will now build all the source files, this process is automated to detect the platform you are running on. If its a red hat or CentOS platform, it will create a .rpm file to install. If you are on Ubuntu/Debian package it will generate a apt-get package.
Another step in the process is to make the install...
make install This will make the installation file ***
Another step in the process is to make the package...
make package This will package up the installation files ready to redeploy***
Next steps: Get the GettingStarted document, and the Using Config Manager document to configure your HPCC system.
